title: Volume after reaction of C4H10 and O2

content.description:
A mixture of two gases, <math alttext="0.01 mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.01</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="C 4 H 10, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>C</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>10</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="0.065 mole " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.065</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="O 2, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>O</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>(</mtext><mi>g</mi><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is pumped into a cylinder with a movable piston, as shown above. The mixture, originally at <math alttext="200 degrees Celsius " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="1.0 atmosphere " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, is sparked and the reaction represented below occurs.

<math alttext="2 C 4 H 10, gas, plus 13 O 2, gas, react to produce 8 C O 2, gas, plus 10 H 2 O, gas" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>C</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> </msub> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>10</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mn>13</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mo>→</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mn>8</mn> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>C</mtext> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>O</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> <mo>+</mo> <mn>10</mn> <msub> <mrow> <mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>H</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> </msub> <mtext>O</mtext> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>g</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math>
content.question: Which of the following is true after the product gases return to the original temperature and pressure, and why will the change occur? (Assume all gases behave ideally.)

choices.label: The piston will be higher than its original position, because the cylinder will contain a greater number of gas molecules.
The position of the piston will be unchanged, because the total mass of the gases in the cylinder does not change.
The position of the piston will be unchanged, because the temperature and pressure of the contents of the cylinder remain the same.
The piston will be lower than its original position, because the product molecules are smaller than the reactant molecules.

content.answer: The piston will be higher than its original position, because the cylinder will contain a greater number of gas molecules.

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
